variant.question: A deployed slat will:

options.text: increase the boundary layer energy and increase the suction peak on the fixed part of the wing, so that the stall is postponed to higher angles of attack.
decrease the boundary layer energy and decrease the suction peak on the slat, so that CLMAX is reached at lower angles of attack.
increase the camber of the aerofoil and increase the effective angle of attack, so that CLMAX is reached at higher angles of attack.
increase the boundary layer energy, move the suction peak from the fixed part of the wing to the slat, so that the stall is postponed to higher angles of attack.

variant.question: The purpose of correctly setting the leading and trailing edge devices on the wing of an aeroplane during take-off, approach and landing is to:

options.text: reduce stall speed, increase CLMAX with minimum increase in drag for take-off, but with a relatively high drag for approach and landing.
increase stall speed and CLMAX during take-off, but reduce stall speed with a relatively high drag during approach and landing.
reduce the take-off roll and increase the landing roll.
reduce stall speed and drag during take-off and landing.

variant.question: The purpose of correctly setting the leading and trailing edge devices on the wing of an aeroplane during take-off, approach and landing is to:

options.text: reduce stall speed, increase CL~MAX~ with minimum increase in drag for take-off, but with a relatively high drag for approach and landing.
reduce stall speed and drag during take-off and landing.
reduce the take-off roll and increase the landing roll.
increase stall speed and CL~MAX~ during take-off, but reduce stall speed with a relatively high drag during approach and landing.

variant.question: An aircraft with trailing edge flaps and leading-edge slats is flying at a speed close to the clean wing stall speed when the flaps are extended to the landing configuration. The slats on the left wing remain retracted. If the speed is decreased, what are the possible consequences?

options.text: The left wing could stall when the trailing edge flaps are extended, after the extension of the slats.
The right wing could stall when the slats are extended, after the extension of the trailing edge flaps.
The right wing could stall when the trailing edge flaps are extended, after the extension of the slats.
The left wing could stall when the slats are extended, after the extension of the trailing edge flaps.

variant.question: During a flight when the trailing edge flaps are lowered to the fully extended position:

options.text: the CP moves to the rear and L/D ratio is decreased.
the CP moves to the rear and L/D ratio is increased.
the CP moves forward and L/D ratio is decreased.
the CP moves to the rear and L/D ratio is unaffected.

variant.question: During a flight when the trailing edge flaps are lowered to the fully extended position:

options.text: the wing CP moves aft and the L/D ratio decreases.
the stalling angle reduces and the L/D ratio increases.
the stalling angle increases and the L/D ratio reduces.
the wing CP moves forward and the L/D ratio increases.

options.text: Deploying a slat will form a slot, deploying a Krueger flap does not.
Deploying a slat will increase critical angle of attack, deploying a Krueger flap does not.
Deploying a Krueger flap will form a slot, deploying a slat does not.
Deploying a Krueger flap will increase critical angle of attack, deploying a slat does not.

variant.question: Which of the following statements about the difference between Krueger flaps and slats is correct?

options.text: Deploying a slat will form a slot, deploying a Krueger flap does not.
Deploying a slat will decrease critical angle of attack, deploying a Krueger flap does not.
Deploying a Krueger flap will increase critical angle of attack, deploying a slat does not.
Deploying a Krueger flap will form a slot, deploying a slat does not.

options.text:
CLMAX is increased but critical alpha is
decreased

CLMAX is decreased but critical alpha is
increased

increased

CLMAX is decreased and critical alpha is
decreased

options.text: increase critical angle of attack.
not affect critical angle of attack.
decrease drag.
decrease CLMAX.

options.text: increase critical angle of attack.
decrease drag.
decrease CL~MAX~.
not affect critical angle of attack.

variant.question: The difference between the effects of slat and flap asymmetry is that: (large in the context of this question means not or hardly controllable by normal use of controls)

options.text: flap asymmetry causes a large rolling moment at any speed whereas slat asymmetry causes a large difference in CLMAX.
flap asymmetry causes a large rolling moment whereas slat asymmetry causes a large yawing moment.
flap asymmetry causes a large difference in CLMAX whereas slat asymmetry causes a large rolling moment at any speed.
flap asymmetry causes a large yawing moment whereas slat asymmetry causes a large rolling moment at any speed.

variant.question: Slat or flap asymmetry occurring after either extension or retraction, may have an effect on controllability since:

options.text: slat asymmetry causes a yawing moment, whereas flap asymmetry causes a large rolling moment.
slat and flap asymmetry both cause a large yawing moment.
slat asymmetry causes a large rolling moment, whereas flap asymmetry causes a large yawing moment.
slat and flap asymmetry both cause a large rolling moment.

options.text: an increase in wing area and camber.
an unaffected CD, at a given angle of attack.
an increase in wing area only.

an unaffected wing area and increase in camber.

an increase in wing area only.

options.text: Low wing Landing

allow space for vibration of the slat.
